channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Blatter 'under investigation in US'
item.description: Outgoing Fifa president Sepp Blatter is being investigated by US officials as part of their inquiry into corruption, US media reports say.

item.title: Hopes fade in Yangtze boat rescue
item.description: Divers spend the night searching a cruise ship which capsized in China's Yangtze River, but the death toll rises to 18 and hundreds are still missing.

item.title: US Senate curtails data collection
item.description: The US Senate approves the Freedom Act so spy agencies can resume data collection, but with major restrictions.

item.title: Greek PM set for Brussels talks
item.description: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is to travel to Brussels where he will be presented with a new plan to solve Greece's debt crisis.

item.title: Early poll plan for Macedonia strife
item.description: The EU says that it has brokered an agreement for early elections in Macedonia to end months of unrest sparked by corruption allegations.

item.title: Australia’s growth beats forecasts
item.description: Australia's economy grew at a better-than-expected 0.9% in the first quarter of 2015, compared to the previous quarter, boosted by mining together with financial and insurance services.

item.title: John Kerry's leg surgery a success
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry undergoes successfully surgery on a broken leg and will be "walking by Wednesday", his doctors say.

item.title: Boston police kill terror suspect
item.description: Officials say the man attacked officers with a large knife after being approached by a Boston police officer and an FBI agent.

item.title: US medals for overlooked WWI heroes
item.description: President Barack Obama awards two World War I army heroes, one black and one Jewish, posthumous medals for their heroics 100 years ago.

item.title: German ex-leader 'in intensive care'
item.description: Germany's former Chancellor Helmut Kohl is in intensive care after surgery on his intestine, German media reports say.

item.title: Hadron collider to turn on data tap
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider is about to pave the way to a new era in physics, as it begins scientific investigations once again after a two-year hiatus.

item.title: Chimps 'have capability to cook food'
item.description: New research suggests chimps have most of the mental capabilities needed to cook food.

item.title: VIDEO: Sepp Blatter's controversial career
item.description: Sepp Blatter says he will resign as president of world football's governing body Fifa amid a corruption scandal - BBC Sport's Natalie Pirks looks back at his career.

item.title: VIDEO: China boat 'capsized so quickly'
item.description: Officials in China say they have not given up hope of finding survivors from a cruise ship that capsized on Monday night.

item.title: VIDEO: Slaves who died in shipwreck remembered
item.description: A ceremony has taken place in South Africa to remember the slaves who died when a ship transporting them from Mozambique to Brazil sank close to Cape Town.

item.title: VIDEO: MH370 relatives settle out of court
item.description: Two Malaysian children whose father was a passenger on flight MH370 have received an out of court settlement for negligence.

item.title: VIDEO: Night footage of Galapagos eruption
item.description: Dramatic footage has emerged of Ecuador's Wolf volcano spewing lava into the ocean.

item.title: VIDEO: Secret tests show US airport security lapses
item.description: A top US official has pledged reforms after tests found that airport screeners allowed mock explosives and weapons through security checkpoints 95% of the time.

item.title: VIDEO: Serious injuries in Alton Towers crash
item.description: Four people have been seriously hurt in a crash between two carriages on a rollercoaster ride at Alton Towers.

item.title: VIDEO: World reacts to Blatter resignation
item.description: As Sepp Blatter steps down, the BBC gauges world reaction to his resignation.

item.title: What will Opec do about the oil supply?
item.description: Oil ministers from Opec meet in Vienna this week to decide whether to cut output or keep pumping crude oil into a market that is already oversupplied.

item.title: Could Rand Paul inspire the UK government?
item.description: Could the new Conservative government develop the libertarian approach favoured by controversial US presidential candidate Rand Paul?

item.title: Odessa's new governor Saakashvili splits opinion
item.description: The choice of Mikheil Saakashvili as Odessa governor in Ukraine is being seen as an unquestionably audacious move, says David Stern in Kiev.

item.title: How would Fifa officials be extradited?
item.description: Seven Fifa officials are facing extradition to the US on corruption charges. How does extradition between the US and Switzerland work?

item.title: Is opposition to GM food irrational?
item.description: Should we embrace technology that could help feed the world, or are concerns about the impact of global agribusiness and industrial food production justified?

item.title: Will the ECB play its ace over Greece?
item.description: The European Central Bank has the ace of trumps when it comes to dealing with Greece's financial crisis. So would they play it?

item.title: Barman Gayle 'signs' for South Devon
item.description: Somerset's former West Indies captain Chris Gayle 'signs' for South Devon and also helps out behind the bar.

item.title: British tank crushes learner driver's car
item.description: A German learner driver gets a tough lesson after pulling out in front of a Challenger 2 tank in Lippe, Germany.

item.title: Sponsors welcome Blatter resignation
item.description: Fifa sponsors welcome Sepp Blatter's resignation but repeat warnings that they expect a swift overhaul of the football governing body.

item.title: VIDEO: BBC World News business headlines
item.description: The latest international business headlines from BBC World News.

item.title: Warnings over IS cyber-threats
item.description: A growing band of hacktivists is helping Islamic State spread its message by attacking media organisations and websites, a security company suggests.

item.title: Egyptian repairman outranks Google
item.description: An Egyptian repairman has managed to outrank Google but nobody seems to be sure how he has done it.

item.title: Redmayne to star in Potter spin-off
item.description: Oscar winner Eddie Redmayne will play Newt Scamander in Harry Potter spin-off Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, Warner Bros confirms.

item.title: Manet Parisian painting up for sale
item.description: An oil painting of a French barmaid, considered one of the defining images of French impressionism, is to be sold at auction later this month.

item.title: Virgin-born sawfish found in Florida
item.description: Seven sawfish in a Florida estuary become the first virgin-born vertebrates ever found in the wild, in a sexually reproducing species.

item.title: 'Moon shot' call on clean energy
item.description: Experts call for "Global Apollo Programme" to tackle climate change

item.title: S Korea has first two Mers deaths
item.description: Two people die of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) in South Korea - the first fatalities from the disease, officials say.

item.title: Canada tobacco firms to pay damages
item.description: A Canadian court orders three tobacco companies to pay C$15.5bn (£8bn, $12bn) - the largest award for damages in the country's history.

item.title: Sepp Blatter to quit as Fifa president
item.description: Sepp Blatter is to resign as president of Fifa amid a corruption scandal and is reportedly under investigation in the US.

item.title: England can still win Ashes - Cook
item.description: England captain Alastair Cook believes his side can beat Australia, despite a crushing defeat by New Zealand at Headingley.

item.title: Drips, leaks and blocked drains in chic Paris
item.description: Paris is a beautiful city but much of its housing stock is in poor condition, notes Hugh Schofield, himself the victim of a series of plumbing disasters.

item.title: Listening to the language of apes
item.description: The similarities between apes and people have long fascinated scientists. Yet, writes Mary Colwell, the differences can be just as thrilling.

item.title: Bhutan breaks tree planting record
item.description: A team of 100 volunteers in Bhutan sets a new world record by planting nearly 50,000 trees in an hour.

item.title: Paris cuts 'love locks' from bridges
item.description: Paris has started removing padlocks symbolically fastened to one of the French capital's main bridges by couples, after part of the Pont des Arts collapsed last year.

item.title: Boko Haram leader not in new video
item.description: Nigeria's militant Islamists release a new video without Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau appearing in it, raising questions about his fate.

item.title: Japanese balloon art hits new heights
item.description: Japanese artist Masayoshi Matsumoto has taken the art of twisting party balloons to new heights with his latest animal creations.

item.title: Russia says old missile downed MH17
item.description: A Russian defence firm says an old Buk missile that it used to manufacture brought down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine.

item.title: US labels Shining Path 'drug gang'
item.description: Peru's Shining Path Maoist rebel group is designated a "significant foreign narcotics trafficker" by the US Treasury.

item.title: Iraq coalition 'winning against IS'
item.description: The US insists a coalition effort to halt the advances of Islamic State in Iraq is succeeding after ministers from 20 countries meet in Paris.

item.title: Quebec separatist Parizeau dies
item.description: Jacques Parizeau, the former Quebec premier who nearly led the French-speaking province to independence, dies at the age of 84.

item.title: All 'failing' schools to be academies
item.description: Every school rated inadequate by Ofsted, up to 1,000 over five years, will become an academy, under a new bill to be published later.

item.title: Body found in missing girl search
item.description: A body is found by police searching for a 13-year-old girl who has been missing for nearly three days.

item.title: Alton Towers closed after ride crash
item.description: Alton Towers is closed while an investigation continues into a "dreadful" rollercoaster accident that left four people with serious injuries.

item.title: Commons tributes for Charles Kennedy
item.description: The House of Commons is to stage a special tributes session for ex-Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, after his sudden death on Monday aged 55.

item.title: In pictures: Senegal's Mouride Islamic sect
item.description: Charms, songs and spirit of Senegal's Muslim brotherhood

item.title: In pictures: Ordnance Survey photo competition
item.description: Stunning images of the British Isles from the Ordnance Survey Photofit competition

item.title: In pictures: Exotic animal rescue
item.description: Reptiles rescued by the RSPCA centre in Brighton

item.title: Drones take whale survey to the sky
item.description: Drones to monitor gray whales of the coast of California

item.title: Pilgrimage to the mountains
item.description: Photographer Timothy Allen climbs high into the Peruvian Andes for Qoyllur Rit'i - the Snow Star Festival.

item.title: In pictures: Edinburgh Fringe poster contest
item.description: Who won? The official poster for the 2015 festival

item.title: Eurovision Song Contest: In pictures
item.description: Party time at the 60th song contest in Vienna

item.title: In pictures: Inside an Indian high court
item.description: Rare access - an Indian high court at work

item.title: The day my daughter was shot in front of me
item.description: The day my daughter was shot in front of me

item.title: Occupation children shunned in post-war Germany and Austria
item.description: The babies Allied forces left behind in Germany and Austria

item.title: Whatever happened to Psy?
item.description: K-pop's plans to conquer the world

item.title: VIDEO: Calligraphy meets graffiti
item.description: The street artist who draws on traditional Arabic calligraphy

item.title: VIDEO: The artist who sold people's Instagram photos ... without asking
item.description: Other people's social media photos taken without permission and sold

item.title: Capturing the 1960s and 70s on film
item.description: Peaceful protests and grieving riots through an amateur's lens
